data.text: If you are touring through different climates and/or are going through places with rain, you might want to do a general chain lube or Tri-Flo
data.author: Jessica Westgren

data.text: isn‚Äôt that chain lube?
data.author: Tdogg Tdogg

data.text: it's for dry weather, which can sometimes be great. Dry lube keeps road grit from hanging onto your chain. But if you hit wet conditions, that lube washes off easily and you will need to reapply more. So for me it depends on where the rider is touring as to which lube they should use.
data.author: Jessica Westgren

data.text: i use this, and the wet-lube and the Ceramic C-lube on my all my bikes. it‚Äôs one of the best along with Finish Line for chain lube. For general climate summer/autumn i use this product. I then switch to the Wet-lube in the winter/spring as i‚Äôm washing the bike more and riding in wetter weather

data.text: Used this for years. I carry some in an eye drop bottle when bikepacking.. usually clean my chain and re lube mid trip
data.author: Lee Joseph Elliott

data.text: Muc-off also do same in a 50ml which is great for touring. It's the one thing we had to buy on our week trip in France as chains dried out
data.author: Richard Record

data.text: They do a ceramic version that is better in a wider range of conditions. I apply about every 200 miles or after rain.

data.text: I use this and their wet lube, I‚Äôve not done any touring myself (yet). These lubes are more suited to a frequent cleaning regime. I think I‚Äôd go with oil for touring where I‚Äôd rather keep maintenance to a minimum

data.text: I've somehow collected a lifetime supply of bottles of lube that just appear. Maybe I'm a spokesman for the, uh, I don't know the brand, the regular black bottles and I think I remember red letters, but don't worry about it unless your bike has a mortgage.
data.author: Roger Komula

data.text: Depends on how long you're out there. Sometimes you just have to settle for whatever the dollar store has.
data.author: Pedaling Pete

data.text: whatever you have, on hand is fine (infinite competing opinions on chain lube to be found) - something is better than nothing...
data.author: Robert Clark

data.text: This is the worst lube for touring. Specially not recommended for long distance. Please find wax lube if possible. They're good for all weather, doesn't need a drive clean every time.
data.author: Satyaki Bhattacharyya

data.text: Here's my take (having covered one or two miles). Big miles will require regular lubricant on the chain. Forget about dry lube unless it's really dry, every day. Imo wipe the chain down at the end of your ride or before you head off again, then reapply a good quality all purpose lube like Fenwicks or Halfords wet lube with teflon. Yes you're applying more lube on top of dirt on a long journey but it's the only way (unless you buy a Rohloff).
data.author: Stuart Leishman
